message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Beyond Western, Educated, Industrial, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD) Psychology: Measuring and Mapping Scales of Cultural and Psychological Distance
Paper Abstract: In this article, we present a tool and a method for measuring the psychological and cultural distance between societies and creating a distance scale with any population as the point of comparison. Because psychological data are dominated by samples drawn from Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic (WEIRD) nations, and overwhelmingly, the United States, we focused on distance from the United States. We also present distance from China, the country with the largest population and second largest economy, which is a common cultural comparison. We applied the fixation index ( F ST ), a meaningful statistic in evolutionary theory, to the World Values Survey of cultural beliefs and behaviors. As the extreme WEIRDness of the literature begins to dissolve, our tool will become more useful for designing, planning, and justifying a wide range of comparative psychological projects. Our code and accompanying online application allow for comparisons between any two countries. Analyses of regional diversity reveal the relative homogeneity of the United States. Cultural distance predicts various psychological outcomes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "World Values Survey"

Links: [{"title":"World Values Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey"},{"title":"Inglehart–Welzel cultural map of the world","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inglehart–Welzel_cultural_map_of_the_world"}]

Here's information about the World Values Survey:

The World Values Survey (WVS) is a global research project that explores people's values and beliefs, how they change over time, and what social and political impact they have.(no content)Since 1981 a worldwide network of social scientists have conducted representative national surveys as part of WVS.(no content)The World Values Surveys were designed to test the hypothesis that economic and technological changes are transforming the basic values and motivations of the publics of industrialized societies, building on the European Values Study (EVS) first carried out in 1981.(no content)Ronald Inglehart of the University of Michigan played a leading role in extending these surveys to be carried out in countries around the world.

The survey measures various dimensions of human values. Analysis of the World Values Survey data by Inglehart and Welzel asserts that there are two major dimensions of cross-cultural variation in the world: survival values versus self-expression values and traditional values versus secular–rational values.

The data from WVS has been used for diverse research purposes, including studying religious orientation, family values, gender attitudes, and government trust across different societies worldwide.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fixation index F_ST genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Fixation index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_index"},{"title":"F-statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-statistics"},{"title":"Genetic distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_distance"},{"title":"Talk:Fixation index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fixation_index"},{"title":"Human Genetic Diversity: Lewontin's Fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Genetic_Diversity:_Lewontin's_Fallacy"},{"title":"Fixation (population genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_(population_genetics)"},{"title":"QST (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QST_(genetics)"},{"title":"Human genetic variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_variation"},{"title":"Fixed allele - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_allele"},{"title":"Talk:F-statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:F-statistics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Fixation Index (FST) in genetics:

## Definition and Purpose

The fixation index (FST) is a measure of population differentiation due to genetic structure.(no content)Developed as a special case of Wright's F-statistics, it is one of the most commonly used statistics in population genetics.

## Data Used

It is frequently estimated from genetic polymorphism data, such as single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) or microsatellites.

## Value Range and Interpretation

Its values range from 0 to 1, with 0 being no differentiation and 1 being complete differentiation. More specifically:

- A zero value implies complete panmixia; that is, that the two populations are interbreeding freely.
- A value of one implies that all genetic variation is explained by the population structure, and that the two populations do not share any genetic diversity.

## Applications

This comparison of genetic variability within and between populations is frequently used in applied population genetics.(no content)For idealized models such as Wright's finite island model, FST can be used to estimate migration rates.

## Example Values in Humans

It is often stated that the fixation index for humans is about 0.15. This translates to an estimated 85% of the variation measured in the overall human population is found within individuals of the same population, and about 15% of the variation occurs between populations.

Web search results for query: "Cultural distance"

Links: [{"title":"Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hofstede's_cultural_dimensions_theory"},{"title":"Power distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_distance"},{"title":"CAGE Distance Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAGE_Distance_Framework"},{"title":"Cultural communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_communication"},{"title":"Chettinad Airport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chettinad_Airport"},{"title":"Michael Muthukrishna - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Muthukrishna"},{"title":"Waterloo Bible College - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterloo_Bible_College"},{"title":"Blake Fitzpatrick - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blake_Fitzpatrick"},{"title":"Nijinsky Stakes (Canada) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nijinsky_Stakes_(Canada)"},{"title":"Principled Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principled_Distance"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about cultural distance:

## Definition and Meaning

Cultural distance refers to the dissimilarity in cultural norms, values, and practices between groups. It's a key concept used in cross-cultural studies to quantify and understand differences between cultures.

## Frameworks for Measuring Cultural Distance

There are several frameworks used to measure and analyze cultural distance:

**Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions Theory**: Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory is a framework for cross-cultural psychology that shows the effects of a society's culture on the values of its members, and how these values relate to behavior. The original theory proposed four dimensions along which cultural values could be analyzed: individualism-collectivism; uncertainty avoidance; power distance (strength of social hierarchy) and masculinity-femininity (task-orientation versus person-orientation).

**CAGE Distance Framework**: The CAGE Distance Framework identifies Cultural, Administrative, Geographic and Economic differences or distances between countries that companies should address when crafting international strategies. Cultural distance affects consumers' product preferences and should be a crucial consideration for a consumer goods or media company, but it is much less important for a cement or steel business.

## Practical Applications

Researchers have argued that a generalised theory of human behavior requires theoretical and empirical understanding of humans across the globe, which can be achieved through the use of cultural distance metrics. Research suggests humans have more similarities in culture than differences, and tools have been developed to measure the cultural distances between different countries.

Comparative psychology is the scientific study of the behavior and mental processes of non-human animals, especially as these relate to the phylogenetic history, adaptive significance, and development of behavior.(no content)In its narrow meaning, it refers to the study of the similarities and differences in the psychology and behavior of different species.(no content)In a broader meaning, comparative psychology includes comparisons between different biological and socio-cultural groups, such as species, sexes, developmental stages, ages, and ethnicities.

### Research Focus

Research in this area addresses many different issues, uses many different methods and explores the behavior of many different species, from insects to primates.

### Historical Development

Charles Darwin was central in the development of comparative psychology; it is thought that psychology should be spoken in terms of "pre-" and "post-Darwin" because his contributions were so influential.(no content)Jacques Loeb emphasized the importance of objectively studying behavior, Sir John Lubbock is credited with first using mazes and puzzle devices to study learning and Conwy Lloyd Morgan is thought to be "the first ethologist in the sense in which we presently use the word".

### Related Fields

Comparative cognition is the comparative study of the mechanisms and origins of cognition in various species, and is sometimes seen as more general than, or similar to, comparative psychology.

Web search results for query: "WEIRD psychology Western Educated Industrialized Rich Democratic"

Links: [{"title":"The WEIRDest People in the World - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_WEIRDest_People_in_the_World"},{"title":"Weird - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weird"},{"title":"Joseph Henrich - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Henrich"},{"title":"Cultural psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_psychology"},{"title":"World Values Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey"},{"title":"Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology"},{"title":"Political spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_spectrum"},{"title":"Doublethink - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doublethink"},{"title":"Popular psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_psychology"},{"title":"Weird Western - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weird_western"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about WEIRD psychology:

## Definition and Origins

WEIRD is an acronym for "Western, educated, industrialized, rich and democratic", and it was coined by Joseph Henrich and his collaborators to refer to the populations most commonly tapped for psychological and behavioral research.

## Purpose and Key Insight

Henrich's research has documented psychological differences across populations around the world, arguing that the most commonly used participants in psychological and behavioral research are not only a single type of population within a global spectrum, but that they are particularly psychologically peculiar.

## Major Work

The WEIRDest People in the World: How the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly Prosperous is a 2020 book by Harvard University professor Joseph Henrich that aims to explain history and psychological variation using approaches from cultural evolution and evolutionary psychology.

## Main Argument

In the book, Henrich argues that a series of Catholic Church edicts on marriage that began in the 4th century undermined the foundations of kin-based society and created the more analytical, individualistic thinking prevalent in western societies.

The WEIRD framework highlights an important methodological issue in psychology research: that findings from Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic populations may not be universally applicable to all human populations worldwide.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Psychological distance"

Links: [{"title":"Psychological distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_distance"},{"title":"Construal level theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construal_level_theory"},{"title":"Distancing (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_(psychology)"},{"title":"Social distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance"},{"title":"Social distance corollary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance_corollary"},{"title":"Distancing language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_language"},{"title":"Psychic distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychic_distance"},{"title":"Universal law of generalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_law_of_generalization"},{"title":"Fear of commitment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear_of_commitment"},{"title":"Similarity (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(psychology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about psychological distance:

## Definition and Core Concept

Psychological distance refers to the relationship between someone and an event, where the greater the distance between the self and an event, the lower the mental perception of importance is for the person.(no content)This psychological distance causes behavioral differences, or non-existence of certain behaviors or attitudes altogether, that alter one's response to an event by changing the perception of its importance.

## Fundamental Characteristics

Psychological distance is fundamentally egocentric, with the anchor point being the self, in the present, and the different interactions of the self with an object or event correlating to the different levels of distance.(no content)Psychologically distant things are often those that are not present or experienced frequently in everyday life, whether the distance is due to a lack of exposure, a lack of knowledge, a temporal difference, or being physically separated.

## Types of Psychological Distance

In Construal Level Theory, psychological distance is defined on several dimensions—temporal, spatial, social and hypothetical distance being considered most important, though there is some debate among social psychologists about further dimensions like informational, experiential or affective distance.

## Connection to Construal Level Theory

Construal Level Theory is a theory in social psychology that describes the relation between psychological distance and the extent to which people's thinking about objects and events is abstract or concrete. The core idea is that the more distant an object is from the individual, the more abstract it will be thought of, while the closer the object is, the more concretely it will be thought of.

## Practical Impact

Several studies have concluded that public concern regarding climate change and environmental issues decreases as one's perceived psychological distance from the issue increases.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete! ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper and populated the triples output with all the key entities and relationships. Here's a summary:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Extracted (6 total):**

1. **World Values Survey** (data) - USES: The primary dataset for analyzing cultural beliefs and behaviors using the fixation index.

2. **Fixation index** (method) - USES: A statistical method from evolutionary theory adapted to measure psychological and cultural distance between populations.

3. **The WEIRDest People in the World** (concept) - USES: The WEIRD framework that the paper builds on to address bias in psychological research toward Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic samples.

4. **Psychological distance** (concept) - PROPOSES: A novel measurement method and tool for quantifying psychological distance between societies.

5. **Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory** (concept) - USES: An established framework for understanding cross-cultural variation that this work builds upon.

6. **Comparative psychology** (concept) - USES: The research field this paper contributes to by providing tools for designing comparative psychological projects.

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and validation has passed successfully!

Sources:
- [World Values Survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey)
- [Fixation index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_index)
- [The WEIRDest People in the World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_WEIRDest_People_in_the_World)
- [Psychological distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_distance)
- [Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hofstede's_cultural_dimensions_theory)
- [Comparative psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_psychology)
